To show that $\bigcap_{alpha}T_alpha$ is a topology on $X$, we need to show that it satisfies the three axioms of a topology:

$emptyset$ and $X$ are both in $\bigcap_{alpha}T_alpha$ since $emptyset$ and $X$ are in every topology ${T_alpha}$.
If ${U_i}{i in I}$ is a collection of sets in $\bigcap{alpha}T_alpha$, then $\bigcup_{i in I} U_i$ is also in $\bigcap_{alpha}T_alpha$. Since each ${T_alpha}$ is a topology, $\bigcup_{i in I} U_i$ is in every ${T_alpha}$, and so it is also in $\bigcap_{alpha}T_alpha$.
If ${U_i}{i in I}$ is a collection of sets in $\bigcap{alpha}T_alpha$, then $\bigcap_{i in I} U_i$ is also in $\bigcap_{alpha}T_alpha$. Since each ${T_alpha}$ is a topology, $\bigcap_{i in I} U_i$ is in every ${T_alpha}$, and so it is also in $\bigcap_{alpha}T_alpha$.
Therefore, $\bigcap_{alpha}T_alpha$ is a topology on X.

Yes, the union of a family of topologies on a set $X$ is a topology on $X$. This is because the union of a collection of topologies on a set $X$ will contain the empty set and the set $X$, and will be closed under arbitrary unions and finite intersections, which are the three properties that define a topology on a set.

It is the smallest topology because if any other topology on X contains all the $T_alpha$, it must also contain this intersection.

The largest topology contained in all $T_alpha$ is the union of all $T_alpha$, denoted as $\bigcup_{alpha} T_alpha$. This is also a topology on X because the union of any collection of topologies on X is also a topology on X. It is the largest topology because if any other topology on X is contained in all the $T_alpha$, it must also be contained in this union.

If C is a basis for a topology on X, then the topology generated by C is the collection of all unions of elements of C. To show that this is equal to the intersection of all topologies on X that contain C, we must show that the generated topology is a subset of any topology on X that contains C, and that it is the largest such subset.

First, we show that the generated topology is a subset of any topology on X that contains C. Since C is a basis for the topology, every element of the topology can be expressed as a union of elements of C. Since every topology that contains C also contains all unions of elements of C, the generated topology is a subset of any topology on X that contains C.

Next, we show that the generated topology is the largest such subset. Let T be the intersection of all topologies on X that contain C. We must show that T is a subset of the generated topology. To do this, we take an arbitrary element of T, and show that it can be expressed as a union of elements of C. Since T is a topology, it is closed under arbitrary unions, so we can express any element of T as a union of basic open sets in T. But since T contains C, every basic open set in T is also an element of C, and so we can express every element of T as a union of elements of C. Thus, T is a subset of the generated topology, and we have shown that the generated topology is the intersection of all topologies on X that contain C.

A topology $mathcal{T}$ on a set $X$ is said to be finer than another topology $mathcal{T}'$ on $X$ if every element of $mathcal{T}$ is also an element of $mathcal{T}'$. In other words, $mathcal{T}$ has more open sets than $mathcal{T}'$. If a topology $mathcal{T}$ is not finer than $mathcal{T}'$ and is not coarser than $mathcal{T}'$, then we say that the two topologies are not comparable.

To show that $R_l$ and $R_K$ are not comparable, we will show that there exists an open set in $R_l$ that is not in $R_K$ and an open set in $R_K$ that is not in $R_l$.

First, consider the set $(0, 1)$. This is an open set in $R_l$ because it can be written as the union of the sets $[0, 1/2) cup [1/2, 1)$, which are both in $R_l$. However, $(0, 1)$ is not in $R_K$ because it contains the point $1/2$, which is in $K$, and the sets in $B$ do not contain any points from $K$.

Now consider the set $(0, 1) setminus K$. This is an open set in $R_K$ because it is in $B$. However, it is not in $R_l$ because it cannot be written as a union of half-open intervals of the form $[a, b)$.

Since there exists an open set in $R_l$ that is not in $R_K$ and an open set in $R_K$ that is not in $R_l$, we can conclude that $R_l$ and $R_K$ are not comparable.

The $epsilon$-$delta$ definition of continuity for a function $f : R \to R$ states that for any $epsilon > 0$, there exists a $delta > 0$ such that for all $x, y in R$, if $|x - y| < delta$, then $|f(x) - f(y)| < epsilon$.

To prove that this implies the open set definition, suppose that $f$ is continuous according to the $epsilon$-$delta$ definition. Let $O$ be an arbitrary open set in the range of $f$, and let $y in O$. Since $O$ is open, there exists an $epsilon > 0$ such that the open interval $(f(y) - epsilon, f(y) + epsilon) subseteq O$. By the $epsilon$-$delta$ definition of continuity, there exists a $delta > 0$ such that for all $x in R$, if $|x - y| < delta$, then $|f(x) - f(y)| < epsilon$. Therefore, for all $x in R$ such that $|x - y| < delta$, we have $f(x) in (f(y) - epsilon, f(y) + epsilon) subseteq O$. Thus, the preimage of the open set $O$ under $f$ is the open set ${x in R mid |x - y| < delta}$, which concludes the proof.

Conversely, if $T'$ is finer than $T$, then for any open set $U$ in $X$, it is also open in $X'$. Therefore, $i^{-1}(U) = U$ is open in $X'$, and so $i$ is continuous.

A function $i : X' \to X$ is a homeomorphism if it is a bijective function and both $i$ and $i^{-1}$ are continuous.

If $T' = T$, then the identity function $i$ is clearly bijective, and since both $T$ and $T'$ are the topologies on the same set $X$, the function $i$ is continuous in both directions and thus $i$ is a homeomorphism.

Conversely, if $i$ is a homeomorphism, then $i$ is a bijective function, and $i^{-1}$ is its inverse, which is also continuous. Thus $i$ is a bijective continuous function, and since $i$ is the identity function, it follows that the topology $T'$ is the same as the topology $T$.

An imbedding is a map that is both injective (one-to-one) and a homeomorphism onto its image.

To show that $f$ and $g$ are imbeddings, we need to show that they are both injective and homeomorphisms onto their images.

Injectivity:
$f(x_1) = f(x_2) implies (x_1, y_0) = (x_2, y_0) implies x_1 = x_2$
$g(y_1) = g(y_2) implies (x_0, y_1) = (x_0, y_2) implies y_1 = y_2$
so $f$ and $g$ are both injective.
Homeomorphism onto its image:
$f$ maps $X$ onto the set ${(x, y_0) | x in X}$ and $g$ maps $Y$ onto the set ${(x_0, y) | y in Y}$.
Since $X$ and $Y$ are topological spaces, and the set ${(x, y_0) | x in X}$ and ${(x_0, y) | y in Y}$ are homeomorphic to them under $f$ and $g$ respectively.
Therefore, $f$ and $g$ are imbeddings.

A homeomorphism is a continuous bijective function between two topological spaces that has a continuous inverse. To show that two spaces are homeomorphic, we need to find such a function between them.

For the first case, we can define the function $f: (a, b) \rightarrow (0, 1)$ by $f(x) = \frac{x-a}{b-a}$. This function is a bijection because it maps every element of $(a, b)$ to a unique element of $(0, 1)$, and it is continuous because it is a ratio of continuous functions. Its inverse is also continuous, given by $f^{-1}(x) = a + x(b-a)$.

For the second case, we can define the function $g: [a, b] \rightarrow [0, 1]$ by $g(x) = \frac{x-a}{b-a}$. This function is also a bijection and continuous, and its inverse is given by $g^{-1}(x) = a + x(b-a)$.

Therefore, we have shown that the subspace $(a, b)$ of the real numbers is homeomorphic to $(0, 1)$ and the subspace $[a, b]$ of the real numbers is homeomorphic to $[0, 1]$ via the continuous bijective functions $f$ and $g$ respectively.

One example of such a function is $f(x) = \begin{cases}x^2 &\text{if } x \neq 0  1 &\text{if } x = 0\end{cases}$

This function is continuous at $x=0$ but not at any other point.

To show that $f$ is continuous when considered as a function from $R_l$ to $R$, we need to show that for any half-open interval $[a,b) subseteq R_l$, the preimage $f^{-1}([a,b))$ is also a subset of $R_l$.

Since $f$ is continuous from the right, we know that $lim_{x \to a^+} f(x) = f(a)$ for any $a in R$. This means that for any $epsilon > 0$, there exists a $delta > 0$ such that if $0 < x - a < delta$, then $|f(x) - f(a)| < epsilon$.

Now, let $[a,b) subseteq R_l$ be any half-open interval. Then, by definition of $R_l$, $f^{-1}([a,b))$ is the set of all $x in R$ such that $f(x) in [a,b)$.

If $f(a) < b$ then since $f(x)$ is continuous on $R$ and $f(a) < b$ we know there is a $delta >0$ such that $f(x) < b$ for all $x in (a, a+delta)$ so $f^{-1}([a,b)) = (a, a+delta) subseteq R_l$

If $f(a) geq b$ then $f^{-1}([a,b)) = emptyset$ which is also in $R_l$.

So in both cases, we have shown that $f^{-1}([a,b)) subseteq R_l$, and thus $f$ is continuous when considered as a function from $R_l$ to $R$.

A function $f : R \to R$ is continuous when considered as a map from $R$ to $R_l$ if and only if for any half open interval $[a, b)$ in $R_l$, the pre-image $f^{-1}([a, b))$ is an open set in $R$.

In general, a function $f$ from one topological space to another is continuous if the pre-image of every open set in the codomain is open in the domain. This is known as the preimage criterion for continuity.

So for a function $f: R \to R$ to be continuous when considered as a map from $R$ to $R_l$, it must satisfy the preimage criterion for continuity when $R_l$ is equipped with the topology generated by half open intervals.

is open in $X$, since the union of open sets is open. Thus, $h$ is continuous.

Because ${A_alpha}$ is locally finite, for each $x$ in $X$, there exists a neighborhood $U$ of $x$ such that $U$ intersects with only finitely many $A_alpha$.
Thus, $f^{-1}(V) = \bigcup_alpha (A_alpha cap f^{-1}(V))$ is a union of finitely many open sets, and is therefore open in $X$.

To show that $f \times g$ is continuous, we can use the fact that the product of two continuous functions is continuous. Since $f$ and $g$ are both continuous, their product $f \times g$ is also continuous.

Alternatively, we can use the definition of continuity. To show that $f \times g$ is continuous, we need to show that for any open set $U subseteq B \times D$, the preimage $(f \times g)^{-1}(U)$ is open in $A \times C$.

Let $U$ be an open set in $B \times D$. Since $f$ and $g$ are both continuous, their preimages $f^{-1}(U_1)$ and $g^{-1}(U_2)$ are open in $A$ and $C$, respectively, where $U_1$ and $U_2$ are the projections of $U$ onto the first and second factors of $B \times D$, respectively.

Now, note that $(f \times g)^{-1}(U) = f^{-1}(U_1) \times g^{-1}(U_2)$, which is the Cartesian product of two open sets, and is therefore open in $A \times C$.

Therefore, $f \times g$ is continuous.

output:
If $F : X \times Y \to Z$ is continuous, then for any open set $U subset Z$, the preimage $F^{-1}(U) = { (x,y) in X \times Y : F(x,y) in U }$ is open in $X \times Y$.

Now consider the map $h : X \to Z$ defined by $h(x) = F(x, y_0)$ for some fixed $y_0 in Y$. For any open set $U subset Z$, the preimage $h^{-1}(U) = { x in X : h(x) in U } = { x in X : F(x, y_0) in U } = { x in X : (x, y_0) in F^{-1}(U) }$ is open in $X$, so $h$ is continuous.

Similarly, for the map $k : Y \to Z$ defined by $k(y) = F(x_0, y)$ for some fixed $x_0 in X$, it holds that for any open set $U subset Z$, the preimage $k^{-1}(U) = { y in Y : k(y) in U } = { y in Y : F(x_0, y) in U } = { y in Y : (x_0, y) in F^{-1}(U) }$ is open in $Y$, so $k$ is continuous.

Therefore, if $F$ is continuous, then $F$ is continuous in each variable separately.

To show that $F$ is continuous in each variable separately, we need to show that for each variable, the function $F$ satisfies the definition of continuity at every point in its domain.

First, we will consider continuity in the variable $x$. To show that $F$ is continuous in $x$, we need to show that for any $(a,b)$ in the domain of $F$ and for any $epsilon > 0$, there exists a $delta > 0$ such that if $|x - a| < delta$, then $|F(x,b) - F(a,b)| < epsilon$.

We can start by using the formula for $F(x,y)$:
$F(x,y) = \frac{xy}{x^2 + y^2}$

Now, we can use the triangle inequality to get:
$|F(x,b) - F(a,b)| = |\frac{xb}{x^2 + b^2} - \frac{ab}{a^2 + b^2}| leq |\frac{xb}{x^2 + b^2}| + |\frac{ab}{a^2 + b^2}|$

We can take $delta = epsilon (a^2 + b^2)$ and if $|x - a| < delta$, then we have $|\frac{xb}{x^2 + b^2}| < \frac{epsilon}{2}$ and $|\frac{ab}{a^2 + b^2}| < \frac{epsilon}{2}$ and thus $|F(x,b) - F(a,b)| < epsilon$

Continuity in variable y can be proven similarly.

Hence $F$ is continuous in each variable separately.

Since $Y$ is Hausdorff, for any $y in Y$, there exist open sets $U_y$ and $V_y$ in $Y$ such that $y in U_y$, $y in V_y$, and $U_y cap V_y = emptyset$.

For any $x in A$, we know that $g_1(x) = f(x) = g_2(x)$. So, let $x in overline{A} setminus A$ and assume that $g_1(x) \neq g_2(x)$. Without loss of generality, assume that $g_1(x) 
otin V_{g_2(x)}$. Then, the set $g_1^{-1}(V_{g_2(x)})$ is an open neighborhood of $x$ in $overline{A}$ such that $g_1(g_1^{-1}(V_{g_2(x)})) subset V_{g_2(x)}$. But since $g_1$ is continuous, $g_1^{-1}(V_{g_2(x)})$ is open in $overline{A}$, which implies that $x$ is an interior point of $g_1^{-1}(V_{g_2(x)})$ in $overline{A}$. This is a contradiction, as $x in overline{A} setminus A$ and $A$ is dense in $overline{A}$.

Hence, we have shown that $g_1(x) = g_2(x)$ for all $x in overline{A}$, and so $g$ is uniquely determined by $f$.
